newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo naphtha rises for fifth successive day.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo naphtha rises for fifth successive day.

text.p: Tokyo naphtha prices rose for the fifth consecutive business day on Monday, buoyed by Friday's overseas crude gains, market participants said.
Higher prices in Tokyo were believed to have made the arbitrage from Europe economically feasible, they added.

"With cheaper freights and the current east-west spreads, the arbitrage window is likely to have reopened," one trader said. However, traders mostly kept to the sidelines, trying to figure out which way the market is heading after naphtha spreads suddenly turned into backwardation last week.
Near-term naphtha spreads moved into backwardation for the first time in three months last Thursday following a flurry of buying of prompt cargoes by a Thai petrochemical company.
The possible resumption of the east-west arbitrage may push spreads back into contango, threatening the Asian markets with surplus cargoes, traders said.
Open-spec naphtha for second-half September was assessed at $205.50/206.50 per tonne.
It was sold at $205.00 on Friday by a Japanese trading house to a Japanese refiner.
